Situation1: Many prospects ask detailed technical questions about the new service that the script only partially addresses.
Expectation2: Respect the privacy and confidentiality of the people you are helping
Situation2: They are sorting files that contain detailed medical histories that must not be disclosed.
Story:
I sat at my desk, headset pressing into my ear, as another call connected. “Hello, this is Alex from BrightNet Services…” The customer on the other end immediately launched into a barrage of technical questions about our new internet package. My script only skimmed the surface, and I could feel my voice falter as I tried to improvise answers, knowing I wasn’t supposed to go off-script. My supervisor expected me to handle objections smoothly, but I was floundering, anxious about giving out incorrect or incomplete information.

Later that afternoon, I hurried to the community center for my volunteer shift. I was assigned to sort confidential medical files—names, diagnoses, treatments—all private, all sensitive. The coordinator reminded us, “Remember, nothing you see here leaves this room.” As I sifted through the papers, I recognized a name from one of my calls earlier. My mind raced: what if someone asked about this person’s health during a sales call? I felt the weight of both roles pressing in—one demanding I answer questions, the other insisting on absolute silence. My chest tightened as I realized I couldn’t possibly satisfy both expectations at once.
